Department of Chemistry University of Kalyani, Kalyani Nadia W.B. 741235 India Recent trends in synthesis of organic fine chemicals using metal incorporated covalent organic frameworks as heterogeneous catalyst clinching appreciable attentions towards researchers. Permanent porosity, high surface area and extremely thermal stable nature makes those covalent organic frameworks (COFs) based materials as appropriate heterogeneous catalyst. The amine-aldehyde modified covalent organic framework constructed zinc catalyst; Zn@DBPG is synthesized and characterized properly. The synthesized material is utilized as an efficient catalyst for the production of organic carbamates following two different pathways: one is carbon dioxide fixation path and another is non carbon dioxide track under mild reaction conditions. In CO2 fixation track, both alkyl halides and aryl halides produced carbamates by reacting with various aromatic amines in presence of Zn@DBPG at room temperature. The absence of a solvent makes this catalytic process more environmentally friendly and greener. Besides, organic carbamate synthesis in non CO2 pathway environmentally benign urea is employed instead of CO2. Aliphatic as well as aromatic alcohols smoothly undergo through this catalytic reaction in ambient reaction conditions. High yield of respective carbamate products are obtained through both catalytic reaction pathways. Again easily separable COF catalyst Zn@DBPG perpetuates its catalytic productivity even after usage of seven catalytic reaction cycles. Besides, feasible mechanism cycles of the catalytic reactions in both pathways established here by DFT calculations. Graphical Abstract Image, graphical abstract Zinc incorporated covalent organic framework based (Zn@DBPG) material have been used to produce organic carbamates in CO2 and non CO2 pathways. Keywords Nanoporous Zn COF Heterogeneous catalysis CO2 fixation Organic carbamates DFT Calculations Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The intricate method for reducing greenhouse gas emissions in recent years is carbon dioxide fixation in response for the creation of valuable products [1–3]. In the fields of synthetic chemistry and green chemistry, CO2 has garnered a lot of attention due to its abundance, renewable nature, low cost, and lack of toxicity [4–6]. Numerous methods for the CO2 fixation reaction have been developed to date, including the cyclo addition of CO2 into epoxides or aziridines [7–9], carboxylation and formylation of aliphatic/aromatic halides [10,11], N-formylation [12], N-methylation [7,13], carbamates production [14], and the formation of oxazolidinones [15], benzimidazoles [16,17], quinazoline [18,19] etc. Among the above said CO2 fixation reactions, the organic carbamates formation reaction have been gaining considerable attentions owing to its significant role in both agricultural [20] and medicinal fields (as pro-drugs and drugs) [21]. As HIV-fighters, they assume a crucial role as well as used as anti cancer, anti-progestational, anti-bacterial, drugs and CNS, CVS active agents [22–27]. The compounds are widely used as linkers in combinatorial chemistry [28,29], as intermediates in organic synthesis [30,31], and for protecting amino groups in peptide chemistry [32]. The synthesis of carbamates typically involves two routes: a CO2 fixation route and a non CO2 fixation route. In non CO2 fixation pathway urea, isocyanates, formamides, dialkyl carbonates etc. are used as C=O sources [33–37]. Organic carbamates were traditionally synthesized using labor-intensive or hazardous reagents such as CO, phosgene and its derivatives [38,39]. It will be simple and extremely appropriate to substitute these chemicals with CO2. For the transformation of amines to carbamates utilizing CO2 as the carbon source, researchers developed a few numbers of homogeneous and heterogeneous metal catalysts based on Ru, Sn, Au, Sn, Cu and Al etc. [40–42]. For further synthesis of carbamates, potassium macrocyclic polyether and potassium superoxide were utilized to improve the reaction conditions [43]. Recently, a range of base-catalyzed or metal-free inorganic and organic systems have been established [44–46] in addition to those catalysts. All of these procedures, however, either call for additional reagents or has low functional group stability, or they necessitate severe reaction conditions like high temperature and pressure. Hence, it is much recommended and ideal to develop a new environmentally favourable, cost-effective technology that performs at room temperature and under atmospheric CO2 pressure. In recent trends Covalent Organic Frameworks (COFs) attributed tremendous attentions to the scientific community on account of its wide spread applications in numerous fields such as gas storage and separation [46,47], energy conversion and retention [48], sensors [49], semiconductors [50,51], optics [52], photocatalysis [53], absorption of solvents under drastic conditions [54], proton conduction [55], biological applications [56] and heterogeneous catalysts [57–65]. Due to the presence of structural beauty, functional diversity, high surface area and permanent porosity, the COFs material exhibited those aforesaid different kinds of applications [66,67]. Again 2D COF formed by repeated arrangement of small organic building blocks have long range of ordered structures and high crystalline networks due to π−π stacking and/or H-bonding [68–70]. Furthermore, the materials have high thermal stability with easily separable power which leads to its successive reusability in the catalytic reaction [71–73]. It is already established that insertion of metal onto COF material produced suitable heterogeneous catalyst for the production of valuable fine chemicals [74–78]. The COF not only functioned as support for the metal catalyst but also have synergistic effect which enhanced the product amount in the catalytic reaction [79–81]. Production of primary carbamates using non CO2 pathway has also been explored by various research groups. In recent years, extensive attentions have been paid to discover eco-friendly and sustainable pathway to synthesize carbamates from isocyanides [82,83], cyanate or isocyanate salts [84,85], azides [86,87], N-acylbenzotriazoles [88], carbonate esters [89–92]. Though, all the methods previously reported showing several disadvantages like drastic reaction conditions, utilization of toxic metal-based catalysts, multi-step procedures and expensive ligands. To overcome those limitations, a cost effective and green pathway of carbamte synthesis has been explored using urea/polyurea as carbonyl source. Beller and co-workers reported carbamate production from urea and alcohol using homogeneous Lewis-acidic FeBr2 catalyst [93]. However, utilising a homogeneous catalyst has its own restrictions in terms of recyclability and reusability. Recently, our group has published couple of papers on this catalytic carabamates synthesis reaction using polymer supported metal based heterogeneous catalyst [94,95]. Here, a heterogeneous catalyst Zn@DBPG has been used for efficient and sustainable synthesis of primary carbamates from urea and alcohol at 50°C and 4-5 h of reaction duration. In this article, we have developed a covalent organic framework (DBPG) from Triformylphloroglucinol and 3,3′-Dimethyl-biphenyl-4,4′-diamine and incorporated zinc metal into the produced COF to synthesize a suitable thermally stable high surface area containing heterogeneous catalyst Zn(@)DBPG. Under green and moderate circumstances, the catalyst (Zn@DBPG) demonstrated outstanding catalytic activity in CO2 fixation processes for the generation of organic carbamates. The organic carbamates were manufactured by using various types of aromatic amines and alkyl halides as well as aryl halides under 1 atmospheric carbon dioxide pressure. Most interestingly the carbamates were manufactured without using any solvent. Also, the catalyst was found extremely efficient in non CO2 fixation carbamate synthesis under ambient reaction conditions using urea and various alcohols. Presence of the heterogeneous Zn@DBPG catalyst enhanced the reactions in both CO2 and non CO2 processes. The readily separable catalyst is utilised for seven catalytic cycles in a row, and the resultant high percentage of desired product yield clearly demonstrates its robust heterogeneity. 2 Experimental Section 2.1 Synthesis of triformyl phloroglucinol (TFPG) Synthesis of the starting material triformyl phloroglucinol was carried out in a large scale. In a 500 ml RB flask, 49 mmol phloroglucinol was mixed with 108 mmol hexamethylenetetramine. In this mixture 90 ml of trifluoro acetic acid was poured. The whole mixture was allowed to stir on a constant heating of 100°C under N2 atmosphere. After 3 hours of heating, to this mixture 150 ml of 3(M) HCl was added. Then the whole mixture was allowed to stir for another 1h at a constant heat of 100°C. This reaction mixture was then cooled to RT and celite was used for filtration. The filtered solution was extracted several times with dichloromethane and dried using sodium sulphate and concentrated on a rotary evaporator to obtain the triformyl phloroglucinol. 2.2 Synthesis of Zn@DBPG Synthesis of Zn@ DBPG catalyst was carried out by reacting 300mg of Triformylphloroglucinol (TFPG) with o-tolidine or 3,3′-Dimethyl-biphenyl-4,4′-diamine (DBD) (200mg) taken in a RB flask using 1.5gm of p-toluenesulfonicacid (PTSA). PTSA and orange o-tolidine were consistently combined in a mortar and pestle and homogeneously ground for 10 minutes to obtain a sticky pale yellowish coloured material. TFPG (100mg) were added to this mixture and grinding was continued for another 15 minutes. The material became yellowish orange in color. To this dough material required amount of distilled water (100-200µL) were added dropwise to make the mixture viscous. Afterwards, the material was transferred in a steel autoclave covered by Teflon reactor and heated at 60°C for first 6h. Then the temperature was increased to 90°C for and continued to heat for another 9h under stable condition. The final catalyst was washed 4-5 times with N,N-dimethylacetamide (DMAc) and then excessive acetone to eliminate any traces of the starting components before being allowed to cool to room temperature. The material was dehydrated under vacuum for 24 hours at room temperature to get the dark orange colored catalyst. (Yield: 85%). The porous Zn-loaded DBPG material was created by combining 100 mg of DBPG material in a powder form with 10 mL of ethanol in a 50 mL RB, followed by 15 mg of ZnCl2.. At 70°C, the mixture was swirled for nine hours. The mixture was filtered and maintained in a desiccator after the reaction was finished in order to get the Zn-loaded catalyst Zn@DBPG. Scheme 1 is showing the synthesis route of Zn@DBPG catalyst. 2.3 Catalytic synthesis of carbamates from amines in CO2 pathway Carbamate synthesis was carried out in a 25 mL round bottom flask fitted with a magnetic stir bar. The flask was filled with 6mmol of amine, 6mmol of halide derivatives, 1.5 eq of Cs2CO3 and 10 mg of catalyst Zn@DBPG. The RB was equipped with a balloon setup filled with CO2, 1 atm. The mixture was allowed to stir for 8h. The reaction advancement was monitored by TLC method in a regular interval. After completion, the reaction, mixture was extracted using EtOAc and work up was done using water and brine solution. The organic layer was separated and dried with sodium sulphate. The product conversion was measured with GC and purified with column chromatography method. All the products were characterized using FT-IR and 1H NMR spectra. 2.4 Catalytic synthesis of primary carbamates from urea in non CO2 pathway 4 mmol of urea was treated with five mmol of alcohol derivatives and 1,4-dioxane (5 ml) in a 25 ml RB. The mixture was added with 10 mg of catalyst Zn@DBPG. The reaction temperature was maintained 50°C for 4 hours of continuous stirring. The catalyst was separated by filtration method with the help of Ethyl acetate as solvent. The filtrate was worked up several times with water and brine solution. At last, the water part was separated and organic layer was passed through Na2SO4 to absorb water molecules. Purified organic layer was analyzed by FT-IR and 1H NMR spectra. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Zn@ DBPG catalyst 3.1.1 Powder X-Ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis Powder X-Ray diffraction characterization was performed on both DBPG and Zn incorporated Zn@DBPG catalyst to know exact arrangement of the synthesized catalyst. PXRD characterization for θ value 20-300 has been done in a very slow rate of 0.20 per minute (Fig. 1 a). For θ= 150- 800, the rate has been increased to 0.50 per minute (Fig. 1b). The PXRD patterns for low angle (20-300) of the nanocatalyst (DBPG and Zn@DBPG) showed prominent high intense unique diffraction peaks which appeared at 2θ = ∼2.4° for the covalent organic framework present in the DBPG, ascribed to the maximum intensity reflection from the Miller plane (100) [75,96]. It demonstrates the excellent crystalline nature of the catalyst Zn@DBPG due to lower rotational flexibility of the building units [75,96]. Incorporation of Zn metal into the COF DBPG didn't affect the crystalline nature of the catalyst as both the catalyst show excellent intense peak at low region. The d spacing value was calculated for (100) facet using Bragg's equation (nλ =2d100sin θ, λ =0.154 nm, n=1 for 100 reflection planes,) and the value is 3.68 nm [90]. Catalyst DBPG and Zn loaded Zn@DBPG both shows prominent peaks at 10.20 and 15.10. These peaks may be assigned to 110 and 210 planes from the COF structure [76]. The wide angle PXRD exhibit peak at 27.40 that may be well assigned to 001 plane. This peak's existence is attributed to a unique interaction that results from the π-π interaction between two adjacent aromatic rings spread upon one another making layered sheets [97]. The existence of these layered sheets may be well established from further characterization techniques like SEM, TEM. The slow scan rate revealed strong peaks for COF attributing 630 and 830 plane at 20.30 and 25.10 [96]. The high angle PXRD (Fig. 1b) confirms successful incorporation of Zn metal into the COF DBPG. The clearly visible intense peaks at 37.20, 400, 41.50, 52.90, 61.90, 68.30 and 73.40 can be assigned to (002), (100), (101), (102), (113), (110) and (004) facets [98,99]. 3.1.2 Fourier Transform Infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy The structure of the suggested catalyst Zn@DBPG was further examined using the FT-IR method. To analyze the structure properly, FT-IR data of both the initial amine (o-tolidine) and aldehyde (TFP) are shown in Fig. 2 along with FTIR data of the catalyst Zn@DBPG. Intense peaks at 1278cm−1 and 1575cm−1 may be ascribed to C-N and C=C/C=O bonds [100]. From IR data it is clearly observed that, the intense peak of aliphatic C-H bond is decreased in the catalyst than the aldehyde as expected. The intensity of the broad peak in range from 3300-3600, which may be ascribed to N-H bond, has decreased for the catalyst than the amine itself. The sharp absorption peaks of –CHO (∼2875 cm−1) for TFP and -NH2 located at ∼3300 cm−1 for o-tolidine is observeved from the FT-IR spectra (Fig. 2). Those peaks are vanished for the as-prepared COF and Zn@DBPG catalytic system, indicating the consumption of -CHO and -NH2 groups of the monomer units. 3.1.3 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis The produced Zinc-containing catalyst Zn@DBPG was prominently characterised using XPS analysis to gather support on the chemical composition and oxidation states. The XPS survey scan of Zn@DBPG material shows all the elements of the metal COF; C, O, N and Zn(II) are present in proper positions as shown in Fig. 3 a. The XPS spectrum for Zn 2p in Fig. 3b shows clearly visible two peaks corresponding to the oxidation state of Zn(II). The sharp peaks positioned at binding energy value 1022.2 eV and 1045.3 eV clearly be distinguished for spin orbital coupling Zn 2p3/2 and Zn 2p1/2 respectively confirming the oxidation state of Zinc to be +2. After deconvulation, the peak assigned for N 1s; two signals were fitted in 398.7 eV and 401.2 eV, depicting N atoms present by means of N-H and C-N (Fig. 3c). In Fig. 3d, O 1s signal was deconvulated into three distinguished peaks at 531.1 eV, 532.4 eV, 535 eV that may be assigned to C=O, C-O and O in H2O. The C=O and C-O signals arrive due to the keto-enol tautomerism occurring in the structure of the catalyst. The C 1s signal determined by XPS technique was well deconvulated into 3 peaks. The resultant peaks arrived at 284.4 eV, 285.4 eV and 287.3 eV. This peaks may be assigned to C-C, C=C (284.4 eV), C-N (285.4 eV) and C=O (287.3 eV) (Fig. 3e). 3.1.4 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) Thermogravimetric analysis of Zn@DBPG sample was performed under N2 atmosphere in-between temperature ranging from 30 to 800°C (Fig. 4 ). From the plot, it is clearly observed that the catalyst is very much stable up to 410°C. Almost no degradation in stability was observed in this range (30-410°C). After 410°C, slow degradation initially followed by steep degradation pattern was noticed around 430°C. It implies that the catalyst would be very much stable and effective in high temperature reactions up to 410°C. 3.1.5 Surface Area Measurement Typical type IV isotherm was appeared for Zn@DBPG catalyst in nitrogen adsorption desorption analysis at 77K (Fig. 5 ). A characteristics hysteresis loop was found in the isotherm in-between the range of 8.0<P/P0 <1.0 [101,102]. The N2 sorption analysis also reveals that the catalyst contains permanent pores in it and most of the pores having the pore size of 2.2 nm (inset of Fig. 5, pore size distribution graph is based on BJH method). The BET surface area of Zn@DBPG is 184 m2/gm. 3.1.6 FE-SEM analysis of Zn@DBPG catalyst To predict the morphology and structure of the catalyst Zn@DBPG, FE-SEM and TEM characterization were performed. As described in Fig. 6 , a-d; SEM images of the catalyst clearly suggest morphology of interlinked twisted wires. SEM Images of the sample in different ranges and several magnifications are taken. A choral like morphology is clearly visible in all the SEM images. The EDAX pattern of Zn@DBPG clearly shows presence of C, N, O and Zn element in the prepared catalyst. The percentage graph of the above mentioned elements are given in SI (Fig. S4). Elemental mapping images of C, N, O and Zn of the catalyst material are shown in Fig. 7 . Amounts of the mentioned elements are in well agreemet with the EDAX pattern shown in Fig. 6f. Fig. 7e shows uniform distribution and growth of Zn particles on COF layer that is supported by the SAED pattern of the catalyst Zn@DBPG in Fig. 8 f. 3.1.7 UHR-TEM analysis of Zn@DBPG To determine the phase of Zn(II) architectured DBPG, tansmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used for characterization. From different magnification of TEM images, layered sheet structure is clearly observed in Fig. 8a-e. In Fig. 6a the sheets like particles in 100 nm range are highlighted in the structure drawn below. Various magnifications were performed from 100 nm range to 20 nm ranges. Those data well accompany the proposed layer sheet structure along with the circled dark spots of metal embedding. Fig. 8f suggests the SAED pattern of the catalyst Zn@DBPG. The well distributed Zn particles on the COF surface are clearly observed as the dark spots are prominent. The hazy dark spots are found due to layered sheet model of this nanoparticle from TEM images are well accompanied with SEM images. 3.2 Catalytic activity of Zn@DBPG 3.2.1 Catalytic carbamate synthesis from amines and halides using CO2 as C1 feedstock Carbamates play an inimitable role in the field of medicinal chemistry as well as in agricultural field. Variety of methodologies was used to synthesize these compounds. In Conventional way, (COCl2) was used to produce the compounds through the reaction of amines and alcohols. Due to the highly toxic nature of Phosgene (COCl2) it is very much essential to make it environmentally benign by replacing the routes associated to phosgene. Keeping this in mind, various protocols have been developed afterwards. Nowadays, usage of dialkyl carbonate; such as diethyl carbonate, dimethyl carbonate, etc. has been increased due to its eco-friendly reaction procedure to produce carbamates from respective amines [103–106]. The most appropriate and preferred method nowadays is to use CO2 as a C1 feedstock to synthesis carbamates from alkyl/aryl halides, amines and alcohols or metal alkoxide/alkoxy silanes,in the presence of a catalyst [107–116]. Previously He et. al. used homogeneous catalyst in presence of K2CO3 /PEG400 to produce carbamate from amines, CO2 and alkyl halides [98]. Recently Das et. Al. used Cs2CO3 as base to synthesize carbamate from alkyl bromide and amines where he used CO2 as C1 feedstock [111]. To improve the above described reaction protocol we developed a Covalent Organic Framework supported by Zn metal (Zn@DBPG) catalyst that can effectively produce carbamates from alkyl halide and amines at room temperature under atmospheric CO2 pressure. Moreover, this heterogeneous catalyst can be reused several times without affecting any significant change in the yield percentage. Initially aniline and iodopropane were taken as model reactants to optimize the catalytic reaction conditions. At first, various organic and inorganic bases were tried to perform the reaction in DMSO solvent under 1 atm CO2 pressure in presence of Zn@DBPG catalyst at room temperature (Schme 2). Organic bases like DBU (1,8-Diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec-7-ene), triethylamine (Et3N) and DIPEA (N, N-Diisopropylethylamine) produced side products showing zero selectivity towards carbamate synthesis (Table 1 , entries 1-3). Inorganic bases like potassium hydroxide (KOH), potassium tert-butoxide (t-BuOK), sodium carbonate (Na2CO3) showed no product yield as well as no reaction improvement (Table 1, entries 4-6). Only Cesium Carbonate (Cs2CO3) was able to produce desired carbamate product in good yield percentage. At first, 1 equivalent of Cs2CO3 was applied to the reaction mixture under DMSO solvent. Desired product was observed with 78% yield without formation of any side products (Table 1, entry 7). Again the increasing of the base amount to 1.5 eq brought 96% desired product (Table 1, entry 8). Thereafter, the reaction was allowed to proceed in solvent free condition. To our utter surprise, desired product was 94% and the further substance variation was performed under solvent free condition (Table 1, entry 9). In absence of catalyst no reaction took place under model reaction condition (Table 1, entry 10). Putting a little amount of catalyst communicated the reaction progress significantly. 10mg of catalyst Zn@DBPG was enough for good yield percentage of desired product (Fig. 9 ). We executed the above catalytic reaction by taking various types of zinc metal precursors instead of our synthesized catalyst but the obtained desired product yields were 18-32% (Table 1, entries 11-13). Again the same reaction was monitored in presence of DBPG COF only; the yield of the desired product was obtained as 48% (Table 1, entry 14). Observing the above catalytic reaction go through smoothly at RT under 1 bar CO2 pressure in neat conditions, we decided to monitor the substance variation under optimized reaction ambience. To our pleasure different types of aromatic amines with alkyl halide and aryl halide gone through the reaction to produce high yield percentage of carbamates products (Table 2 , entries 1-7).Aniline's electron-donating and electron-withdrawing substituents both achieved the desired product with excellent selectivity and conversion. . We also tried the carbamate synthesis from benzylamine. It also showed good product yield while reacting with both aliphatic and aromatic halides (Table 2, Entry 3,4). 3.2.2 Catalytic carbamate synthesis from urea and alcohols Utilizing urea and a variety of both aliphatic and aromatic alcohols in the presence of the catalyst Zn@DBPG, primary carbamates were produced (Scheme 3 ). Initially, propanol was taken as a model substrate to check the uniformity of the catalytic process. Firstly the standardization was done by taking 5mmol propanol, 15mg Zn@DBPG catalyst and 4mmol of urea in addition with 5 ml acetonitrile at room temperature. With our utter surprise the reaction produced 27% (Table 3 , Entry 1) of the desired product yield and it motivated us to further study and modifies the reaction conditions to get better percentage of product yield. Upon increasing the temperature to 50°C, desired product yield increased effectively to 59% (Table 3, Entry 2). Further increasing of the temperature to 80°C product yield percentage reduced due to the formation of bicarbamate side products (Table 3, Entry 3). Afterwards, several different solvents like benzene, DMSO, DMF, Toluene, DCM, water were used for carbamate formation (Table 3, entries 4-10). Though none of the above solvents performed well as compared to 1,4 Dioxane. In presence of Dioxane, very impressive yield percentage (93%) of propyl carbamate (Table 3, Entry 10) was produced. It led us to the decision to use Dioxane for further study of carbamate synthesis from urea and alcohol. Without solvent only trace amount of corresponding carabamte was obtained (Table 3, entry 11). When the catalyst amount was enhanced to 15mg, there was no alteration of product yield percentage under optimized catalytic reaction conditions (Table 3, entry 12). Use of no catalyst in the model reaction produced only trace amount of desired carbamate product (Table 3, entry 13). Instead of synthesized catalyst we employed metal precursors such as zinc chloride [ZnCl2], zinc nitrate [Zn(NO3)2], zinc acetate dihydrate [Zn(CH₃CO₂)₂·2H₂O] as catalyst for the reaction, 28-36% of propyl carbamate was formed (Table 3, entries 14-16). While COF DBPG was utilized as catalyst, moderate yield (53%) of carbamate was obtained from the reaction (Table 3, entry 17). In both type of catalytic reactions in presence of synthesized COF material (DBPG) as catalyst produced moderate yield of carbamate product [propyl phenylcarbamate: 48% (Table 1, entry 14 and propyl carbamate: 53% (Table 3, entry 17)]. Therefore COF material has a fair catalytic activity towards these carabamates formation reactions. Although presence of zinc metal in the COF material enhanced this activity into the excellent level. Thus both COF and zinc metal has the synergistic effect in order to perform efficient catalytic activity. Therefore, various alcohols were used for substrate variation using urea and 10mg of catalyst Zn@DBPG at 50°C under dioxane solvent. Both aliphatic alcohols and aromatic alcohols (benzyl alcohol and phenol) effectively went through well in the carbamate formation reaction. Initially two different types of aliphatic alcohols; propanol and butanol were used under optimized reaction conditions. Propyl carbamate from propanol was produced in an excellent yield of 93% after 4h of reaction (Table 4 , entry1). Butyl carbamate from butanol was also produced in very good yield (96%) after same reaction duration (Table 4, entry 2). Then, benzyl alcohol and derivative of benzyl alcohol, 4-methoxy benzyl alcohol were treated with urea, very good percentage of respective carbamates product i.e. 92% and 95% respectively were obtained (Table 4, entries 3, 4). Afterwards phenols (such as phenol and 4-methoxy phenol) were tested for carbamate formation reaction. Both phenol and 4-methoxy phenol produced good percentage of carbamate yield as 81% and 85% respectively after relatively longer reaction interval (5h) (Table 4, entries 5, 6). Phenylethyl alcohol produced highest amount of carbamate yield (97%) as compare to the other alcohols (Table 4, Entry 7). Therefore it was found that phenol and its derivative produced comparatively lower amount of desired products after more reaction time span due to the p-π conjugated effect for direct attachment of alcohol group to the benzene ring. 3.2.3 DFT calculations for the prediction of probable reaction mechanism of catalytic carbamates formation reaction through non CO2 and CO2 fixation pathways The PXRD of Zn-COF exhibits that there is Zn(II) center which is able to coordinate to urea through the O-atoms of urea [93–95]. To realize the mechanism of the carbamate synthesis reaction between methyl alcohol (ROH) and urea catalyzed by Zn-COF, the theoretical calculations were accomplished using DFT/LanL2Dz for full catalytic observations (theoretical calculation details are in ESI). From former results [93–95] and the experimental outcomes, it was compared that urea molecule is initiated by the interface of the zinc atom of Zn-COF by the oxygen donor atom of urea (structure-I) which can take responsibility to initiate the said catalytic reactions. The respective energies for all intermediates involve in catalytic reaction of ROH and urea in attendance of Zn-COF is presented in Fig. 10 . The catalytic site of Zn-COF is primarily considered as zero for the whole calculations. Firstly, the Zn-COF coordinated via Zn(II) ion with oxygen atom (dZn(II)…Ourea =2.88Å) from urea and grows the electrophilic character at the carbonyl carbon in urea which is tending to the formation of intermediate-I (-17.20 × 103 kcal mol−1). Further, the catalytic reaction was continued forward, in where the very reactive nucleophilic such as methyl alcohol (ROH) tends at the carbonyl carbon of urea as electron deficient centre to form an intermediate–II (structure II) with respective energy of -19.5 × 103 kcal mol−1. Then, the intermediate-II is simultaneously, undergoing an intramolecular proton transfer from protonated methyl alcohol (ROH) to the amine group of urea and form an intermediate-III (-20.11 × 103 kcal mol−1) which is the zinc coordinated ammonium intermediate. Both intermediate -II and –III are in equilibrium by their relative energies. In the last moment of the catalysis, the removal of ammonia molecule from intermediate –III after auto-decomposition of the ammonium compound by breaking of oxygen to zinc co-ordinate bond (dZn(II)…Ourea =2.89Å) and releases the final product carbamate. After releasing of carbamate, the Zn(II) is coordinated with urea to give re-birth of catalytic initiation by Zn-COF, which is the main criteria of a catalyst that remains intact and unaffected after completion of catalytic reaction cycle. The above-mentioned major steps are compiled with three intermediates between start of the journey of catalysis and the final product. The respective energies attained for Int-1, Int-2, Int-3 and product are -17.20 × 103, -19.5 × 103, -20.11 × 103 and -3.79 × 103 kcal mol−1, respectively. The probable mechanism is structured (Fig. 11 and Fig. S6) upon the evidenced from experimental results and theoretical simulations for the catalytic reaction of urea and methyl alcohol to form methyl carbamate. The above-mentioned mechanism is the good agreement with previous reported articles [93–95]. The PXRD of Zn-COF exhibits that there is Zn(II) center which is able to coordinate to methyl amine and CO2 through the O-atoms of the addition compound of methyl amine and CO2 that is the key leading force for the enriched catalytic carbamate synthesis. To realize the mechanism of the carbamate synthesis reaction between amine (RNH2), halide (RX) and CO2 catalyzed by Zn-COF, the theoretical calculations were accomplished using DFT/LanL2Dz for full catalytic observations (theoretical calculation details are in ESI). The respective energies for all intermediates involve in catalytic reaction of methyl amine (MeNH2), ethyl bromide (EtBr) and CO2 in attendance of Zn-COF is presented in Fig. 12 . The catalytic site of Zn-COF is primarily considered as zero for the whole calculations. Firstly, the Zn-COF coordinated via Zn(II) ion with oxygen atom (dZn(II)…O =2.18Å) from the addition compound of methyl amine and CO2 and grows the electrophilic character at the carbonyl carbon in the said addition compound which is tending to the formation of intermediate-I (structure I) (-14.85 × 103 kcal mol−1). Further, the catalytic reaction was continued forward, in where the very reactive nucleophilic such as methyl amine (RNH2) tends at the oxygen of addition compound as electron deficient center to form an TS–I (structure II) with respective energy of -10.9 × 103 kcal mol−1. Then, the TS-I is simultaneously, undergoing further interaction with ethyl bromide (EtBr) by replacing alkyl amine from addition compound and form an intermediate-II (-15.69 × 103 kcal mol−1) with the removal of HBr and methyl amine. In the last moment of the catalysis, by breaking of oxygen to zinc co-ordinate bond (dZn(II)…Ocarb =3.08Å) released the final product as carbamate. After releasing of carbamate, the Zn(II) is coordinated with alkyl amine and CO2 to give re-birth of catalytic initiation by Zn-COF, which is the main criteria of a catalyst that remains intact and unaffected after completion of catalytic reaction cycle. The above-mentioned major steps are framed with two intermediates and one transition state between start the journey of catalysis and the final product. The respective energies attained for Int-1, TS-1, Int-2 and product are -14.85 × 103, -10.9 × 103, -15.69 × 103 and -7.36 × 103 kcal mol−1, respectively. The probable mechanism is structured (Fig. 13 and Fig. S5) upon the theoretical simulations for the catalytic reaction of CO2, methyl amine (RNH2) and ethyl bromide to form methyl ethyl carbamate. 3.3 Recyclability of Zn@DBPG The reusability and recyclability of Zn@DBPG catalyst was screened for the carbamate synthesis reaction for both CO2 and non CO2 pathways. After completion of every reaction cycle, the used catalyst was separated out via simple filtration process. The separated catalyst was then washed with acetone several times. After washing Zn@DBPG carefully, it was then put under vacuum desiccators. The separated, washed and dried Zn@DBPG was then used in another catalytic reaction cycle. To our utter pleasure, the onetime reused catalyst was equally stable as the fresh sample. The catalyst was used for six times for both of the reactions following the cleaning measures properly. It was very much efficient for carbamate synthesis even after sixth cycle of reaction for both CO2 and non CO2 pathways (Fig. 14 ). 3.4 Heterogeneity Test Heterogeneous nature of a catalyst is the most important feature that is measured in industrial application. To determine the heterogeneity nature of the catalyst, we performed a hot filtration test with both of the carbamte formation process including CO2 and non CO2 pathways. At first, we have taken aniline and iodopropane in presence of Cs2CO3 and our synthesized catalyst Zn@DBPG at room temperature under CO2 balloon and solvent free conditions. After initial 8 hours of reaction progress, the yield percentage of desired product was obtained 68% from the reaction mixture. After 8h of continuous reaction we removed the catalyst by filtration method from the reaction mixture and the reaction was further carried out for another 8h in absence of the catalyst. No further reaction progress was observed. Following the hot filtration test, the filtrate underwent ICP-AES analysis. No trace of Zn metal was found in the residue filtrate. The Zinc loading was found 4.95% to 4.63% after first and sixth cycle respectively via ICP-AES analysis. However, only after sixth catalytic reaction, a dramatic decrease in catalytic activity might be caused by blocking of the catalyst's active sites. Afterwards, urea, propanol, 1,4 dioxane and Zn@DBPG were taken at 50°C temperature. We have monitored the reaction under our catalyst for initial 2h. Yield percentage of the propyl carbamate produced was 59%. Then, the catalyst was removed by hot filtration method and the reaction was continued to proceed for another 2h in absence of Zn@DBPG catalyst. No further reaction progress was observed. We analyzed the filtrate got from hot filtration test with ICP-AES analysis. Residue filtrate was found Zn free. However, Zinc loading was discovered to be 4.95% to 4.44% after first and sixth cycle. 4 Conclusions Zinc metal embedded covalent organic framework catalyst Zn@DBPG was synthesized and characterized by PXRD, FTIR, XPS, TEM and SEM analysis and nitrogen sorption study. This catalyst was used in effective carbamate production in both CO2 and non CO2 fixation pathways. Preparation of organic carbamates from aromatic amines and both alkyl as well as aryl halide in presence of the catalyst was performed via CO2 fixation reaction in existence of Cs2CO3 base. High percentage of desired product yield was appeared at room temperature from this catalytic reaction. The well organized catalytic reaction without any solvent is the most important part of the reaction. In non CO2 pathway; urea and various types of aliphatic and aromatic alcohols produced very high percentage yield of desired carbamtes products. The catalytic effectiveness of Zn@DBPG was not diminished much after sequential use of seven cycles. The heterogeneity, easily separable and rework able nature of the catalyst proves its industrial importance under current scenario. Again, theoretical calculation (DFT) was carried out in order to predict the probable mechanism cycles for both type of catalytic reactions. coredata.dc:description: Recent trends in synthesis of organic fine chemicals using metal incorporated covalent organic frameworks as heterogeneous catalyst clinching appreciable attentions towards researchers. Permanent porosity, high surface area and extremely thermal stable nature makes those covalent organic frameworks (COFs) based materials as appropriate heterogeneous catalyst. The amine-aldehyde modified covalent organic framework constructed zinc catalyst; Zn@DBPG is synthesized and characterized properly. The synthesized material is utilized as an efficient catalyst for the production of organic carbamates following two different pathways: one is carbon dioxide fixation path and another is non carbon dioxide track under mild reaction conditions. In CO2 fixation track, both alkyl halides and aryl halides produced carbamates by reacting with various aromatic amines in presence of Zn@DBPG at room temperature. The absence of a solvent makes this catalytic process more environmentally friendly and greener. Besides, organic carbamate synthesis in non CO2 pathway environmentally benign urea is employed instead of CO2. Aliphatic as well as aromatic alcohols smoothly undergo through this catalytic reaction in ambient reaction conditions. High yield of respective carbamate products are obtained through both catalytic reaction pathways. Again easily separable COF catalyst Zn@DBPG perpetuates its catalytic productivity even after usage of seven catalytic reaction cycles. Besides, feasible mechanism cycles of the catalytic reactions in both pathways established here by DFT calculations.
coredata.dc:title: Zinc incorporated covalent organic framework (Zn@DBPG): an efficient catalyst for the synthesis of carbamates through CO2 and non CO2 fixation pathways under sustainable condition
